subject: Football
event:
Life is meaningless and has no purpose.

I don't know which was more painful, watching the Giants lose again to the Cowboys, or sitting in a sports bar in Saratoga as the Colts collapsed and Evil Little Bill and his Patriots won another one.  Damn you, Belicheat!  Damn you, Brady!  Damn you, Stego!

I have a sick feeling in the pit of my stomach that we're headed toward a Cowboys - Patriots Superbowl.  There's no teams I loathe more.  I'll have no one to root for.  Is there some way both of them can lose?

Unless the Cowboys choke, it looks as though a grisly death is in store for Patrick St. Denis.  I think I'll kill a couple of guys named Romo and Teo along with him.

(Sits down to sharpen his axe).

comments.article: The Steelers will have something to say about the AFC side of things before all is said and done.
comments.subject: best not forget...

comments.article:
I couldn't believe the Colts vs. Pats game. I had such hope.

Giants gotta get it done with the Lions or we are talking 2 half meltdown again.

And does anyone have any idea where the Jets might be in the draft now?
Tied with Rams, ahead of Dolphins.

Mr. Martin, sir, may I draw your attention to this thread, in which I (accurately, it seems) predicted that the Jets would struggle to win even just five games this year...?

Of course, this isn't to say I didn't think they could win at least two, but such is life.

Well, my life.
Go Packers?

Life is meaningless and has no purpose.

That's true, regardless of how your favorite team is doing.

Which reminds me, is there any chance of more stories set in the universe of The Way of Cross and Dragon? It's the story the turned me on to your other work, and it holds special place in my mind.
The Steelers remain our only hope.

Belicheat = Bolton! I don't care which one. Now go make that evil bastard pay. You'll make me proud, I'm sure.

P.S. Don't count out those Colts just yet... or the Packers either.
comments.subject: channel that rage!!!

comments.article: If you're going to try and draw parallels between ASOIAF and the NFL, the only character that Belichick could possibly be is Jaime Lannister. He's a got a record of victory, he sticks by his word (even though everyone despises him and mistrusts him), he ALWAYS pays his debts, and even when you censure him (fine, loss of pick/ loss of swordhand) he's still an amazingly formidable opponent.
comments.subject: Honestly...
well, if you're talking about the North
Re: well, if you're talking about the North
Have you watched Bill's press conferences?
Re: Have you watched Bill's press conferences?
Re: The series isn't over yet

comments.article:
Cowboys/Patriots=Lightning Strikes? Repeat, freak of nature lightning strikes? That hit both sidelines? Hopefully?

Look at it this way; even if the Patriots went all the way, the victory would be in the shadow of Belichick being revealed as a cheating little asshole this year.
Don't worry, this will be the Lions year. I feel it in my waters. ;)

I had seats two rows back from the Giants's endzone for their game with the Cowboys. Lots of fun, but it certainly added to the misery of that embarrassing defeat.

I'd say the Colts are done challenging the Patriots for this season. They're so injured right now, and losing Dwight Freeney for the year is an absolutely lethal blow to their defense. The Steelers may be able to challenge though. Their only two losses this year came to the Cardinals and the Broncos. On the surface, these are two terrible losses, but when you break them down they're not so bad. Both were on the road. The Cardinals' head coach is Ken Wizzenhunt, who only last year was coaching in Pittsburgh. He knows the weaknesses of the players, which enabled him to come out with a solid game-plan. And I'll toss the Broncos loss out the window. That thin mountain air took its toll on the defense. Other than the Broncos, the only teams even remotely used to to playing in that stadium are in the same division. So it comes down to what the Steelers do against the Patriots in their upcoming match. A win would be nice, but so long as the Steelers play them close I have faith they could challenge the Pats in the post-season.

As to the NFC, the Packers may be able to challenge the Boys. Three games ago, they had everything but a running attack. But over the last two games, Ryan Grant has rushed over 100 yards, including against the Vikings, a team with a very strong rushing defense. Grant doesn't need to be great, just good. The Packers' passing attack is so lethal this year they can actually use it to set up their run. If Ryan Grant can keep it up, the Packers are a legitimate threat. That Packers-Cowboys in a few weeks will be huge.

As to those Giants ...they need to keep revamping that secondary in the off-season. Aaron Ross looks pretty good for a rookie, but Sam Madison and McQuarters are old. We also need better safeties. Gibril Wilson makes big plays, but he also gives up the big pass. The other guy is a joke. And Eli needs to step up!
remeber to feed their man-parts to the goats :-)

Yes, the Colts game was painful to watch. We're just so decimated with injuries right now -- we only had 15 offensive players active by the end of the Chargers game, and now Dwight Freeney is on IR? *weeps*

I really think that's what did us in against the Patriots -- Peyton was so limited on his passing options with Harrison and Gonzales out that he had to rely on Addai way too much, so Joseph was exhausted by the last quarter, so we couldn't get anything done on offense, especially any kind of long drive. Our defense had to keep taking the field, and they were exhausted by the fourth quarter. The Patriots challenged and we were out of gas.

It's not just injuries; we should have played better in the second half overall. But it wasn't like the Chargers game with kick and punt returns for TDs and six interceptions. We just didn't have enough in the tank at the end.

We'll get 'em in the playoffs. ^_^

Isn't it interesting that in last year's AFC champ game your Dolts won because they were so good and not because the Pats' D was decimated by injuries. This year you have they injuries so now injuries are a legit excuse. Hypocrite
Can't we at least make some sort of sacrifice to The Lord of Light and ask that it be Green Bay vs. Pittsburg?
comments.subject: meaningful and purposeful

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: boom headshot
comments.article: After I left you with that ne'er-do-well, Stego, I worried the whole miserable drive back to NYC. And I was CRUSHED when I heard the final score. Bah. At least you both made it out of the bar alive -- I wondered if we'd find Stego's corpse in a shallow grave after one-too-many Brady taunts (the punk).
BWAH-HA-HA!!11
I am so looking foward to seeing all these Patriots and Cowboys dying in ADWD.

comments.upictitle: Madam Lulzy the Great: Deedlit Relaxing
comments.article: MWAHAHAHA

I'm basking in your collective anguish right now, and reveling in the knowledge that the only thing that's going to save you all from a Super Bowl Championship being won by a team whose cheating coach should be unemployed is the Dallas Cowboys.

You're all quite welcome.
I messed with Texas once...  I got away with it.

"Life is meaningless and has no purpose." Being a Seahawks fan, I resemble this remark. I just hope Alexander stays benched long enough for Mo Morris to thoroughly prove himself.

They could pull themselves together and actually get somewhere in the playoffs... in an alternate dimension.
Yeah. :(
Yeah, whatever George.  Go Pats!
comments.subject: Sour Grapes?

comments.article:
I may just be a hopeless Colts fanboy, but I predict they're still in it. The Patriots felt just a little exposed in that game, and coming out of a bye is always a little unpredictable.

Still, was a tough game with those evil Cowboys. The Giants are my wife's team (she picked the "cuter" Manning), so we were pretty irritated.

I'm holding out hope for a Packers/Colts Superbowl. Enough already with the stupid Patriots and their devil worship.
comments.subject: Holding out hope

comments.article:
I grew up with the Cowboys. Always on Thanksgiving they would play. I live in Texas see, so I have an excuse.

Anyway, when i was in my early teens, that's when the Cowboys took THREE consecutive victories in the Super bowl. I knew no other game to be so awesome and inspiring for just a team that's in my home state.

Well, except for UT's Rose bowl a few years back. Ahhh.... Now that was a game.

So goooo Cowboys! I think i am going to add hot chili to my queso this year.

; }
comments.subject: Aww common!

comments.article:
Dude. Any self-respecting Cowboy fan can tell you that they won three championships in four years -- not three consecutive championships. You just make the rest of us Cowboy fans look bad when you post stuff like that.

That being said, the Cowboys are a great story to follow. We've been down for so long -- wandering in the wilderness without any answer at quarterback -- that to actually have a guy who can make plays for us . . . Man. I can't even describe what it feels like to actually have hope again.
comments.subject: Re: Aww common!

comments.article: As a Bears fan for the bulk of my life, it pains me to root for Green Bay to go all the way. It'd be a nice swan song for Favre if nothing else--he may play for the Pack, but I still have great respect for him. A Cowboys-Pats Super Bowl would just be.... ewyuch...

Brett Favre is a great player, and a good guy as well. It would be a real Cinderella story if he ended his career hoisting the Lombardi trophy.

And you know, he was almost a Jet. The Jets were ON THE PHONE with him when he was drafting. They were saying, "We're going to be taking you next pick, Brett. There's only Atlanta yet to go, and they don't need a quarterback, so once they pick we'll send up your name and bring you to New York and... "

And Atlanta promptly picked Favre. Then they sat him on the bench for a year and promptly traded him to Green Bay.

The Jets got Browning Nagle.

This is the kind of special torment that satan inflicts on Jets fans.
comments.subject: Brett

comments.article:
I'm a Redskins fan - always have been, always will be, 110%. I like the Jags and the Panthers, both of whom seem to be doomed, and I like the Packers. Of those 4, only the Pack has a decent chance, and I will cheer any NFC team over the damned Convicts. I'll even, very grudgingly, cheer for Philly or the GIants over the Cowboys, though I'll choke on every word and hate myself for it. So, go Packers!

My dad's family is from New England, and I rather like the Patriots (in a neutral, no-reason-to-hate-them kind of way), but oh, I cannot STAND the Colts.

comments.upictitle: Madam Lulzy the Great: Deedlit Relaxing
comments.article: Maybe I'll get punched in the face for this, but, at least it's just a game, eh?

This was a rebuilding season for the KC Chiefs. That's my excuse, and I'm sticking to it.

There's always next year.
The Chiefs have been rebuilding since Super Bowl III.  I have utterly no sympathy for that club.

Evil Bill is starting to grow on me. And not like a fungus. I really like his audacity, and ruthlessness. As for the Colts, I don't think I could stomach any more preaching. I guess God must not like them as much this season.

I don't think dem Cowboys will make it to the Superbowl. They are a very good team that's peaking too soon. Romo will wake up and remember he's not Staubach. T. O. will start dropping critical balls.

Of course, the Gints will upset the apple cart on week 17 and life will be good in Giant land.

Caveat. Given my track record none of this will happen.
comments.subject: Ya Know...
